attributes.title: Investigating the effect of U = U messages on HIV stigma.

q1.value: Investigating the effect of U = U messages on HIV stigma.

q3.value:
Recent HIV research has indicated that People Living With HIV (PLHIV) with an undetectable viral load who adhere to Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) are not at risk of transmitting HIV to their sexual partners (Rodger et al., 2014). In 2016, the Prevention Access Campaign, whose aim in part is to end HIV-related stigma, launched the U=U initiative to disseminate the slogan Undetectable = Untransmittable.
PLHIV have been identified previously as a group vulnerable to facing stigma. In the context of HIV, this form of stigma is comprised of prejudiced beliefs and negative attitudes about PLHIV. This can manifest in three ways: enacted stigma (direct, overt negative attitudes and behaviours towards PLHIV), perceived stigma (beliefs held by PLHIV regarding the negative attitudes of others), or internalised stigma (adoption by PLHIV of negative attitudes and beliefs about themselves) (HIV Ireland, 2017). Stigma is associated with a number of negative outcomes for PLHIV, including poorer adherence to medication, lower rates of HIV testing, and decreased quality of life for PLHIV (Mahajan et al., 2008). Researchers have identified several factors which drive this form of stigma, including fear of transmission (Napper, Reynolds & Fisher, 2010), and social norm enforcement (Stangl et al., 2019).

The effects of being exposed to messages promoting the finding that Undetectable = Untransmittable (U = U) remain unclear. Research on health message dissemination has suggested that the use of framing plays a key role in the effectiveness of a message (Angst & Agarwal, 2009). This research tends to fall under the framework of the Elaboration Likelihood Model (ELM; Petty & Cacioppo, 2012). Under this framework, information is processed via two pathways – the central and peripheral route. It has been demonstrated that the quality of a message positively influences the perceived usefulness of the information being conveyed (Bhattacherjee and Sanford, 2006). The ELM has previously been applied to HIV research, demonstrating that a high-quality message was more effective than a low-quality message at reducing HIV risk behaviour (Dinoff & Kowalski, 1999). Whether this finding can be extended to decreasing HIV stigma has been largely untested

In this study, the efficacy of an Undetectable=Untransmittable message in decreasing HIV stigma will be compared to a message that is unrelated to HIV. The current study also seeks to investigate whether an evidence-based message will be more effective at decreasing HIV stigma through the use of central cues such as the quality of the message, and peripheral cues such as the credibility of the source, than an opinion-based message, which makes poor use of central and peripheral cues. Finally, the study seeks to evaluate the role of issue involvement as a covariate in the relationship between message framing and attitude change.

q4.value:
H1(a): There will be an effect of U=U messages on self-reported stigmatised beliefs about people living with HIV when compared with an unrelated message control condition. 
H1(b): An evidence-based U=U message will have a stronger positive impact on participants’ self-reported stigmatised beliefs about people living with HIV than an opinion-based message. 
H2: An evidence-based U=U message will have a stronger positive impact on U=U perceived accuracy than an opinion-based message.
H3: Issue involvement will act as a covariate, moderating the effect of a U=U message on HIV stigma.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants will be asked to take part in a research study on the effects of health messages on beliefs and attitudes in relation to HIV. After reading the participant information sheet they will be asked if they consent to taking part in the study.  Participants will complete an online questionnaire. All participants will first be asked a sequence of demographic questions - age, gender, sexuality, and a rating from 1 to 10 on how strongly they feel they can relate to PLHIV. The participants will be randomised into one of three conditions. In the control condition, participants will be asked to read a short internet article that is unrelated to HIV (the use of preventers/inhalers in the treatment of asthma). In experimental condition 1, participants will be asked to read a short internet article about the research findings and science behind Undetectable=Untransmittable. In experimental condition 2, participants will be asked to read a short internet article about a celebrity discussing their knowledge of Undetectable = Untransmittable. All participants will then be asked to complete two brief measures: the Perceived Risk of HIV Infection Scale (PRHS), and a shortened version of the Stigmatising Attitudes towards PLHIV scale. Finally, participants will be asked to rate from 1 to 10 how accurate they perceive the U=U slogan to be, and whether they had heard of U=U before taking part in the study. All participants will then be debriefed and thanked for participating in the study. The procedure is expected to take 20 minutes in total.

q9.value: We will use block randomisation, in which each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three equally sized, predetermined blocks. The randomisation tool in the LIME Survey software that will be used to collect data will be responsible to random assignment.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Non-probability sampling strategies (convenience sampling and self-selection) will be used to recruit participants for this study. Participants will be able to access the study through the ‘SONA’ system, and via university email. Participants recruited through the ‘SONA’ system will be psychology undergraduate students, and anyone with a link to the study will be able to access it. Relevant NGOs will be engaged with to promote the study on social media. Participants must be at least 18 years of age to participate in this study.

q13.value: The proposed sample size for this study is 204.

q14.value: The statistical program G*Power was used to conduct power analysis. Adhering to Cohen’s (1988) criteria for small (r=0.1) medium (r=0.3), and large (r=0.5) effects, a two-tailed alpha of .05 was assumed for all tests. With 3 groups (HIV-unrelated message, evidence-based message, opinion-based message), a small-medium effect size (which is the smallest effect size of interest; Lakens, 2014), and a power of 0.8, the recommended sample size for a between groups one-way ANOVA was 204; 68 participants in each group.

question.value: The independent variable in this study will be the message content, with three levels: HIV-unrelated message (control), evidence-based U=U message, and opinion-based U=U message.

HIV Stigma, measured by the Perceived Risk of HIV Infection Scale and the shortened Stigmatising Attitudes Towards People Living with HIV Scale.  
Perceived accuracy of the U=U message will be measured by a question asking participants to rate from 1 to 10 how accurate they perceive U=U to be.
Issue involvement will also be measured using post-hoc analyses as a covariate of the effect of message framing on self-reported stigmatised beliefs, operationalised by rating from 1 to 10 of how strongly participants feel they can relate to and empathise with the experiences of people living with HIV.
The mean score of the two scales above will be calculated to generate an overall 'HIV Stigma' score. The score obtained on each scale will also be examined independently.

To analyse H1(a) and H1(b), a between groups (HIV-unrelated message, evidence-based message, opinion-based message) ANOVA will be conducted. H2 will also be analysed using a between-groups (evidence-based message, opinion-based message) ANOVA, in which the dependent variable will be perceived accuracy of the U=U message. H3 will be analysed using a one-way (HIV-unrelated message, evidence-based message, opinion-based message) ANCOVA, in which the covariate in this study, issue involvement, will be controlled for.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA, ANCOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: We will verify that each subject answered each of the HIV Stigma measures. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete any of the two measures of HIV Stigma, then their data will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to U=U awareness and perceived accuracy. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, sexual orientation, condom usage, HIV status, PrEP usage) and U=U awareness and perceived accuracy.

attributes.title: Prevalence of osteoporosis in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus in the Chinese mainland

q1.value: Prevalence of osteoporosis in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus in the Chinese mainland: a protocol of systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Yuhao Si, Cenyi Wang, Hao Yu, Yang Guo, Yong Ma, Heng Yin

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Inclusion criteria
Studies that meet the following criteria will be included in our review:
1.	Participants from mainland China diagnosed with T2DM.
2.	Study design being a cross-sectional study or cohort study.
3.	Equipment utilized to test BMD should be dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry.
4.	Tested area is lumbar or hip.
5.	Outcomes are pooled prevalence estimates and the prevalence rate for each risk factor.
6.	Published in English or Chinese. 
Exclusion criteria
Studies that meet the following criteria need to be excluded from our review:
1. Participants diagnosed with other types of diabetes mellitus.
2. Review, case report, letter, or abstract.
3. A duplicate report.
4. The information regarding prevalence estimates and risk factors can not be directly extracted or obtained from the corresponding author.
Search strategy
Four English databases (PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, Cochrane Library) and two Chinese databases (China National Knowledge Infrastructure, Wanfang Database) will be retrieved from their inceptions to May 2020. The electronic search strategy is accessible in Supplemental Digital Content. Moreover, we will also conduct a manual search in the library of Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine and Duquesne University in case of any missing literature. 
Selection of studies 
Two members of our workgroup will independently screen the titles and abstracts of potential articles, then read the whole contents to further identify the eligible studies by employing the drafted inclusion and exclusion criteria. A third reviewer will be an arbitrator to make a judgment when disputes arise. Additionally, the two reviewers will record the results of selection (authors, titles and publication year) in a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet (Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, WA), and another reviewer will supervise the whole process. The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Flowchart will be filled in by the end of the study selection to provide specific information. 
Data extraction and management
The four aspects of data will be extracted from the eligible studies: characteristics of studies (e.g., the first author, publication year, study design, the equipment for BMD assessment, the tested body parts, the place where the study was conducted), participants (e.g., sample size, response rate, age, gender, BMI, type and duration of diabetes, place of residence, living habits), biomarkers (e.g., level of blood glucose, GHb, triglyceride), results (overall number of osteoporosis cases, stratified number of osteoporosis cases by each factor). Two reviewers will create a spreadsheet to save all the extracted data as mentioned, and another reviewer will supervise the whole process. If some necessary data can not be found or calculated from the potential studies, we will email or call the corresponding author to ask for assistance. Furthermore, the study will be excluded if the missing data cannot be acquired after contacting the corresponding author. 
Assessment of risk of bias in individual study
Two reviewers will independently assess the risk of potential bias in each study applying the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS), which is devised for nonrandomized studies. The NOS consists of three aspects, which are the selection of study groups, comparability, and assessment of outcome. Based on the three aspects, a total score ranging from 0 to 9 points will be measured, and a study with a total score of greater than 7 points is defined as a high-quality study. Any disagreement will be determined by a third reviewer.
Data analysis and synthesis
We will conduct this study on the basis of at least two studies employing the software Stata version 12.0. We will display all the information extracted from the eligible studies via plotting summary tables, flow diagrams, or graphs, depending on the necessities. It should be noted that we prefer to choose the random-effect model to calculate the pooled prevalence estimates since the prevalence estimates tend to vary among different populations. The heterogeneity among studies will be quantified via applying the I2 index. Moreover, a narrative synthesis will be performed when the meta-analysis is not suitable to be administered.
Publication bias
The Begg’s test, as well as the Egger’s test, will both be utilized to judge the potential publication bias. Additionally, the trim and fill method will be employed if the results of the Begg’s test and the Egger’s test demonstrate that substantial publication bias exists. 
Subgroup analysis 
It is essential to conduct the subgroup analysis in this study in order to screen the potential osteoporosis-related risk factors among Chinese diabetics. The subgroup analyses will be executed in accordance with the various types of participants (e.g., ethnic groups, BMI, age), regions (e.g., economics status, living habits, medical resources, climate) and some other information regarding the study design (e.g., year and sample size).

Two reviewers will independently assess the risk of potential bias in each study applying the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS), which is devised for nonrandomized studies. The NOS consists of three aspects, which are the selection of study groups, comparability, and assessment of outcome. Based on the three aspects, a total score ranging from 0 to 9 points will be measured, and a study with a total score of greater than 7 points is defined as a high-quality study. Any disagreement will be determined by a third reviewer.
Data analysis and synthesis
We will conduct this study on the basis of at least two studies employing the software Stata version 12.0. We will display all the information extracted from the eligible studies via plotting summary tables, flow diagrams, or graphs, depending on the necessities. It should be noted that we prefer to choose the random-effect model to calculate the pooled prevalence estimates since the prevalence estimates tend to vary among different populations. The heterogeneity among studies will be quantified via applying the I2 index. Moreover, a narrative synthesis will be performed when the meta-analysis is not suitable to be administered.
Publication bias
The Begg’s test, as well as the Egger’s test, will both be utilized to judge the potential publication bias. Additionally, the trim and fill method will be employed if the results of the Begg’s test and the Egger’s test demonstrate that substantial publication bias exists. 
Subgroup analysis 
It is essential to conduct the subgroup analysis in this study in order to screen the potential osteoporosis-related risk factors among Chinese diabetics. The subgroup analyses will be executed in accordance with the various types of participants (e.g., ethnic groups, BMI, age), regions (e.g., economics status, living habits, medical resources, climate) and some other information regarding the study design (e.g., year and sample size).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Search strategy
Four English databases (PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, Cochrane Library) and two Chinese databases (China National Knowledge Infrastructure, Wanfang Database) will be retrieved from their inceptions to May 2020. The electronic search strategy is accessible in Supplemental Digital Content. Moreover, we will also conduct a manual search in the library of Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine and Duquesne University in case of any missing literature. 
Selection of studies 
Two members of our workgroup will independently screen the titles and abstracts of potential articles, then read the whole contents to further identify the eligible studies by employing the drafted inclusion and exclusion criteria. A third reviewer will be an arbitrator to make a judgment when disputes arise. Additionally, the two reviewers will record the results of selection (authors, titles and publication year) in a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet (Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, WA), and another reviewer will supervise the whole process. The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Flowchart will be filled in by the end of the study selection to provide specific information. 
Data extraction and management
The four aspects of data will be extracted from the eligible studies: characteristics of studies (e.g., the first author, publication year, study design, the equipment for BMD assessment, the tested body parts, the place where the study was conducted), participants (e.g., sample size, response rate, age, gender, BMI, type and duration of diabetes, place of residence, living habits), biomarkers (e.g., level of blood glucose, GHb, triglyceride), results (overall number of osteoporosis cases, stratified number of osteoporosis cases by each factor). Two reviewers will create a spreadsheet to save all the extracted data as mentioned, and another reviewer will supervise the whole process. If some necessary data can not be found or calculated from the potential studies, we will email or call the corresponding author to ask for assistance. Furthermore, the study will be excluded if the missing data cannot be acquired after contacting the corresponding author.

attributes.title: Optimizing an Unknown Social Welfare Function to Aid Public Decision-Making
attributes.description: The purpose of the research is to understand and improve the negotiation process of a group of individual decision-makers when faced with a public decision (e.g., voting on a policy choice). Specifically, the study will evaluate different ways group welfare functions can be modeled in order to best fit the society’s values.

q1.value: Optimizing an Unknown Social Welfare Function to Aid Public Decision-Making

q3.value:
A classical utilitarian perspective on public decision-making is that the public should choose an alternative that maximizes some function over the utilities of individuals, called a social welfare function. If the utility function for each decision-maker is cardinal and comparable with other decision-makers, then there are many valid social welfare functions. The problem is then finding the social welfare function that implicitly best fits society’s values.  In other words, the group decision problem is a problem of maximizing an unknown social welfare function implicitly held by society. While there is a wealth of literature on possible social welfare functional forms based on different information assumptions, we are proposing an empirical approach that will predict a group's social welfare function based on both individual preferences and group voting behavior, and observe whether the group agrees with the recommendation.

We propose to tackle this challenge taking advantage of the ongoing Democratic Party 2020 Presidential Primary and recruit participants in groups to discuss on specific climate change/energy policy alternatives. The study is divided into three stages:  1) individual elicitation (30 minutes), 2) clustering (immediate), and 3) group decision-making (45 minutes). In Stage 1, individual utility functions are estimated for each person using choice data from a two-alternative forced choice task.  In Stage 2, decision-makers are clustered into groups based on the choices they made in Stage 1. In Stage 3, participants are randomly assigned to one of two treatment arms in groups of 4 and asked to discuss on an energy policy future for the US.

q4.value:
There are two treatment arms in the study: a) recommendations generated through a weighted sum algorithm that assumes a linear social welfare functional form, and b) recommendations generated without assuming linear social welfare functional form. Our hypotheses include:

1) Participants are more likely to reach a positive consensus for the second treatment arm than the first treatment arm because it can better capture non-linear social welfare function forms such as the min or the max function. 

2) Participants will be more likely to prefer the recommendation over other alternatives for the second treatment arm than the first treatment arm because it can better capture non-linear social welfare function forms.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This study is divided into three stages: 1) individual elicitation (30 minutes), 2) clustering (immediate), and 3) group decision-making (45 minutes). ). In Stage 1, individual utility functions are estimated for each person using choice data from a two-alternative forced choice task.  In Stage 2, participants are clustered into groups based on the choices they made in Stage 1. In Stage 3, participants are randomly assigned to one of two treatment arms in groups of 4 and asked to come to discuss an energy/climate policy for the US.

The aim of Stage 1 is to elicit individual utility functions over energy policies for each decision-maker in the sample.  Preferences are elicited for everyone over energy policy alternatives defined by four attributes with 3, 6, 3, and 3 levels, resulting in a total of 168 attribute combinations (policy alternatives). The complete policy alternatives characteristics (including all attributes and their levels) are listed in the attached table. Participants make 44 choices, and all participants are given the same choice sets. Individual utility functions are generated for each participant. From pilot testing we expect each question to take approximately 30 seconds. In addition, participants take between 5-10 minutes to read the introductory material to the task. The stage will then take up to 32 minutes (22 minutes for 44 questions at 30 seconds each, plus up to 10 minutes for introductory material). 

The second stage clusters participants into groups based on the choices they made in Stage 1. The aim is to construct groups that are a stratified sample of participants, where stratification is across groups of participants with heterogeneous preferences. This is required to prevent groups from having participants who all agree with each other, which would make for an uninformative experiment in Stage 3. However, research participants are not involved in this stage. Participants who answered negatively to planning to vote in the 2020 Democratic presidential primary will be excluded at this stage. 

In the third stage, each group created in stage 2 will be randomly assigned (single blind) into one of two treatment arms. Groups are briefed at the beginning of this task and told that their goal is come to a negotiated decision about energy policy given the attributes discussed in stage one. In addition to the personal compensation each participant will receive, each group will also be told that if the group agrees to the recommended policy alternative, the Democratic Presidential Primary candidate that had the closest proposed policy to the group consensus will receive a nominal donation ($10). If the group does not reach a consensus, then the nominal donation will be given to a random candidate. This is to ensure that participants are motivated to meaningfully engage in the exercise. Randomly donating the money to a candidate in the case of no consensus will ensure strategy proofness. 

Stage 3 is further divided into three distinct phases for both treatment arms. In the first phase, 15 policy comparisons (2 alternatives) are shown to the group one at a time, and participants are asked to select one of the two alternatives that they believe the group should choose. Each group will have two minutes for each comparison, and participants must make vote before the end of the two minutes. Participants do not have to agree before making their vote, but they are encouraged to discuss with others in their group and  share their perspectives and opinions with each other.

After phase one is complete, phase two starts and the group will be presented with one recommended policy alternative. Different treatment arms will generate the recommended policy alternative through different algorithms, but participants will not see any difference between the treatment arms. Participants must vote on whether they are willing to accept this policy alternative for the group. Similar to phase one, participants have two minutes to discuss between themselves, and they must vote before the end of the two minutes. 

Once the group finishes phase two, phase three starts. During phase three, the group must make an additional 10 comparisons (similar to phase one), however, one of the two alternatives for each comparison is the recommended policy alternative generated in phase two. In addition, participants will only have 30 seconds to vote for each comparison. After phase three, the participants are compensated and the study ends. 

Analysis will be conducted at the group level (between subject design on whether groups accept the recommendation, and win rate of recommendation against random alternatives) and individual level (between subject design clustered on groups, measuring on whether each individual accepted the recommendation, win rate of recommendation against random alternatives, and regret of the recommended solution against their individual utility function).

q9.value: During stage two of the study, after all eligible participants are clustered into the four stratified clusters, groups are generated by randomly selecting a participant from each cluster using a random number list from random.org. During stage three of the study, a group is randomly assigned to a treatment arm when they arrive for the study. They will be given a random number between 1 and 2, and if they receive 1, they will go to treatment arm one, and if they receive 2, they will go to treatment arm two. The random number is generated using random.org.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through a combination of on campus flyers and access to Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) Center for Behavioral and Decision Research (CBDR) participant pool. All participants who successfully complete stage one of the study (individual survey) will be entered into a draw to win one of five 50$ Amazon gift cards. In addition, if a participant is recruited for stage three of the study, they will be paid $10 for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old to participate, able to converse in English, and stage three will exclude participants who answered "No" to whether they plan to vote in the 2020 Democratic Primary.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 240 participants divided into 60 groups of four participants. Each treatment arm will have 30 groups. For our planned individual analysis, individuals will be clustered at the group level. We will attempt to recruit up 360 individuals, assuming not all individuals will complete the task and are available for all stages of the experiment.

q14.value: Given our study relies on the current 2020 Democratic Presidential Primary, we must complete data collection before Pennsylvania holds its primary vote (April 15). In addition, in order to ensure participants are not significantly influenced by the changing political realities of the primary process, we would like to complete this study before majority of candidates drop out.

question.value:
On an individual level, each individual utility function is generated using the following attributes: Nuclear Power (N), Price on Carbon ($/ton of CO2) (CO2), Fossil Fuel Exploration on Federal Lands (FFE), and Federal Clean Energy Portfolio Standard (FCEP). N, FFE, and FCEP are treated as categorical variables with three levels each, while CO2 is treated as a continuous variable. However, six CO2 levels are used to generate each policy alternative. The full list of attribute levels with their descriptions can be found in the attributeTable.html file attached. 

The utility function is modeled as a standard logit model:

U = B0 + B1 * N1 + B2 * N2 + B3 * CO2 + B4 * FFE1 + B5 * FFE2 + B6 * FCEP1 + B7 * FCEP2

B0 is the model intercept, while B1 - B7 represent the variable coefficients for each individual participant. 

On a group level, treatment arm one will will make policy recommendations using a weighted sum algorithmic approach. The group social function will take the following form: 

GroupScore = B1*P1 + B2 * P2 + B3 * P3 + B4 * P4

Where P1 - P4 represent the individual utility of person 1 - 4 for an alternative, and B1 - B4 represent the weight value for each individual. 

Treatment arm two will make policy recommendation using a non-linear algorithmic approach. The group social function is estimated as: 

GroupScore = Ubar + K * SD

Where Ubar is the average utility for each alternative, SD is the standard deviation of the utility for each alternative, and K is the parameter that determines the estimated form the social welfare function. K is bounded between -0.5 to 0.5. If K is -0.5, then the group social welfare function will have a min functional form. If K is 0.5, then the group social welfare function will have a max functional form. If K is 0, then the group social welfare function is a utilitarian (equal weighted sum of individual utilities) form.

On a group level, the following outcome variables will be measured for each group:

1) Binary variable on whether the group accepted the recommended policy (0 for no, 1 for yes). All members of the group must vote yes for a group to accept the recommended policy.

2) A score out of 10 that measures the group's win rate in phase three of stage three. A group will get one point every time all members of the group chooses the recommended solution over the random policy alternative.

3) The ranking of the group's recommended policy if it was calculated using an equal weighted sum of all individual utilities.

4) The regret of the group's recommended policy, measured as the difference in group utility value between the recommended policy and the top ranked policy calculated using an equal weighted sum of all individual utilities. 

On the individual level, the following outcome variables will be measured:

1) Binary variable on whether the individual accepted the recommended policy (0 for no, 1 for yes).

2) A score out of 10 that measures the individual win rate in phase three of stage three. A person will get one point if that person chooses the recommended solution over the ranom policy alternative.

3) The ranking of the group's recommended policy for that individual's utility ranking.

4) The regret of the group's recommended policy, measured as the difference in the private utility between the recommended policy and the top ranked policy for that individual.

Our primary between-subjects analyses will be:
1) A two-sample randomization test of the proportion of groups reaching consensus on the recommended alternative across the two treatment arms. Consensus is defined as all participants in the group voting for the recommended alternative. The total sample size is n = 30 for each treatment arm. We will follow this up with t-test and KS test as secondary testing procedures to test for robustness, but will report the randomization test as our main analysis.
2) A two-sample randomization test of the average number of votes in favor of the recommended alternative across the two treatment arms in the validation phase. Each participant votes for the recommended alternative or for an alternative option in the validation phase, and repeats this 10 times. Thus, there are a total of 40 possible votes in favor of the recommended alternative for the group, so each group will have 1 score that ranges from 0 to 40. These will be averaged across the groups then compared across treatment arms. The total sample size is n = 30 for each treatment arm. We will follow this up with t-test and KS test as secondary testing procedures to test for robustness, but will report the randomization test as our main analysis.
3) The first analysis will be repeated but at the individual level using a mixed logit model. Each individual's vote within a group will be counted as 1 if they vote in favor of the recommended alternative, and zero otherwise. The model will use random intercepts at the group level. The primary hypothesis is that the second treatment arm will lead to a higher probability of individual votes in favor of the recommended alternative than the first treatment arm.
4) Our final analysis will repeat the second analysis but at the individual level. We will use a mixed logit model of the probability of voting in favor of the recommended alternative during the validation phase of the study. The model will include both group-level intercepts and individual-level intercepts. The primary hypothesis is that the second treatment arm will lead to a higher probability of individual votes in favor of the recommended alternative than the first treatment arm.

q20.value:
The coding scheme for each categorical variable is as follows:

Nuclear Power:

0 - Keep current nuclear power plants but do not build any new plants.
1 - Keep current nuclear power plants and provide money to increase nuclear power by 14% over the next eight years.
2 - Shut down nuclear power plants that are not making money, reducing nuclear power by 14-29% than today. Do not build nuclear plants in the next eight years.

Fossil Fuel Exploration on Federal Lands:
0 - Unregulated access to federal lands and waters for fossil fuel exploration.
1 - Tighter fracking regulation on public lands that increases storage safety standards and transparency of what chemicals are used.
2 - Fully ban fossil fuel exploration on public lands.

Clean Energy Standard Target:
0 - Starting from 2021, reach 100% clean energy by 2100 with a yearly increase of 1.3% of clean energy in the grid. 
1 - Starting from 2021, reach 100% clean energy by 2050 with a yearly increase of 3.5% of clean energy in the grid.
2 - Starting from 2021, reach 100% clean energy by 2035 with a yearly increase of 7.5% of clean energy in the grid.

q21.value: We will use alpha = 0.05 as our threshold for determining statistical significance in all models.

q22.value:
We have added two reversal checks in the individual surveys. The last two comparisons in the survey is the same as two randomly selection comparisons in the first 42 comparisons, with only the orders reversed. If the participant's response is inconsistent, we will still include their data, but we will conduct a with and without analysis to ensure that did not affect the final result. 

For the group, we will ask three attention check questions at the end of the verbal briefing to ensure they understand the task. If they answer incorrectly, we will still include their data, but will conduct a with and without analysis to ensure that did not affect the result.

q23.value: For stage 1 of the study, if a participant does not finish the survey, they will not be invited to stage 3, and their data will be discarded. For stage 3 of the study, if a group is unable to complete the task, their data will be discarded. Otherwise, missing data will be dropped casewise. For example, if a participant does not complete all of the validation phase, the incomplete elements will be excluded, but the rest of the data included.

q24.value: We plan to examine the individual utility functions from the first phase of the study and how those utility functions change after the group task. We are also interested in whether individual utility functions shift toward one cluster of decision-makers more than others. To do this we can calculate the distance of each decision-maker to each cluster's vector of attribute weights before vs. after the group task, then compare them using a linear mixed model. We will also examine the best ex-post fit to social welfare functions using several functional forms (linear, mean-SD, min, max), tested through cross-validated ROC curves. We will also examine whether demographics are related to individual and group preferences using a mixed logit model.

If K is 0.5, then the group social welfare function will have a max functional form. If K is 0, then the group social welfare function is a utilitarian (equal weighted sum of individual utilities) form.
registration_responses.q17.question:
On a group level, the following outcome variables will be measured for each group:

1) Binary variable on whether the group accepted the recommended policy (0 for no, 1 for yes). All members of the group must vote yes for a group to accept the recommended policy.

2) A score out of 10 that measures the group's win rate in phase three of stage three. A group will get one point every time all members of the group chooses the recommended solution over the random policy alternative.

3) The ranking of the group's recommended policy if it was calculated using an equal weighted sum of all individual utilities.

4) The regret of the group's recommended policy, measured as the difference in group utility value between the recommended policy and the top ranked policy calculated using an equal weighted sum of all individual utilities. 

On the individual level, the following outcome variables will be measured:

1) Binary variable on whether the individual accepted the recommended policy (0 for no, 1 for yes).

2) A score out of 10 that measures the individual win rate in phase three of stage three. A person will get one point if that person chooses the recommended solution over the ranom policy alternative.

3) The ranking of the group's recommended policy for that individual's utility ranking.

4) The regret of the group's recommended policy, measured as the difference in the private utility between the recommended policy and the top ranked policy for that individual.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Our primary between-subjects analyses will be:
1) A two-sample randomization test of the proportion of groups reaching consensus on the recommended alternative across the two treatment arms. Consensus is defined as all participants in the group voting for the recommended alternative. The total sample size is n = 30 for each treatment arm. We will follow this up with t-test and KS test as secondary testing procedures to test for robustness, but will report the randomization test as our main analysis.
2) A two-sample randomization test of the average number of votes in favor of the recommended alternative across the two treatment arms in the validation phase. Each participant votes for the recommended alternative or for an alternative option in the validation phase, and repeats this 10 times. Thus, there are a total of 40 possible votes in favor of the recommended alternative for the group, so each group will have 1 score that ranges from 0 to 40. These will be averaged across the groups then compared across treatment arms. The total sample size is n = 30 for each treatment arm. We will follow this up with t-test and KS test as secondary testing procedures to test for robustness, but will report the randomization test as our main analysis.
3) The first analysis will be repeated but at the individual level using a mixed logit model. Each individual's vote within a group will be counted as 1 if they vote in favor of the recommended alternative, and zero otherwise. The model will use random intercepts at the group level. The primary hypothesis is that the second treatment arm will lead to a higher probability of individual votes in favor of the recommended alternative than the first treatment arm.
4) Our final analysis will repeat the second analysis but at the individual level. We will use a mixed logit model of the probability of voting in favor of the recommended alternative during the validation phase of the study. The model will include both group-level intercepts and individual-level intercepts. The primary hypothesis is that the second treatment arm will lead to a higher probability of individual votes in favor of the recommended alternative than the first treatment arm.

attributes.title: LGBQ in STEM: A Matter of Gender - Study 2
attributes.description: This study explores the effect of experimentally manipulated gender essentialism (i.e., gender is binary, fixed, and biological) on gender-science stereotypes (i.e., science is masculine) and people's evaluation of LGBQs fit in STEM academic disciplines.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
LGBQ in STEM: A Matter of Gender - Study 2. An experimental investigation of the role of gender essentialism and gender-science stereotypes to the inclusion of LGBQs in STEM.

We consider this to be a valid pre-registration as data collection is underway and we have not looked at the data collected yet. Our intent is to be transparent and maintain accountability in the way we will treat our data and test our hypothesis. For this reason, we have given and extensive presentation of the data analysis protocol that we are going to follow, and have explained how each analysis that we will carry out connects to our study design.

other.value:
We would like to register the other measure included in the study (i.e., gender science stereotypes), and the entire protocol of statistical analyses that we intend to follow. This was the main reason for us to register the study, and to maintain a high standard of transparency and accountability in our research process.

Measure of gender-science stereotypes

After the evaluation task, the participants continue to the last part of the study: our measure of gender-science stereotypes. First, the participants complete a short memory task: in two minutes, they are asked to write down anything they remember about the neuroscientific article. This task was used to increase the effect of the manipulation of gender essentialism on gender-science stereotypes as well as to test whether the participants remembered the article until the end of the study. At this point, the participants were asked to rate 30 gendered traits on a 7-point scale of importance (i.e., How important are each of the following traits to become a successful scientist in STEM?). The participants then completed a traditional measure of gender-science stereotypes (i.e., How much do you associate science with men/women?), that we used in Study 1. We decided to compare these two measure to investigate in more depth this stereotypes.


Demographic questions

In the last section, the participants give some background information: sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, ethnicity, political orientation, annual income, religious orientation, age, year of university attended.


Data analyses protocol

1. Manipulation check
Each participant will be assigned a score based on the number of correct answers they gave to the four true/false questions regarding the article. The participants that do not have any correct answer will be excluded from further analyses. The score of the participant will be added to our last model as a covariate, to check if the results change. If we do not find an effect of gender essentialism on the resumes’ evaluations, this last model will allow us to understand whether our hypothesis is wrong, or if there is something wrong with our manipulation of gender essentialism (e.g., the article was too complex).
Similarly, the level of agreement with the conclusion of the article will be added as a covariate in our last model, again for comparison reasons. In case a main effect of gender essentialism is not found, we will be able to understand if our hypothesis is wrong or if the participants showed resistance to our manipulation.

2. Missing data
We are going to perform a missing values inspection in SPSS, for both variables and cases. We do not expect MNAR (missing not at random) due to the questions being ambiguous, too difficult, or causing resistance because we (a) hide the aim of the study carefully, and (b) state clearly that specific knowledge or skills are not necessary to complete the survey. We do not expect a lot of MAR/MCAR (missing at random) due to the participants skipping a question because (c) the number of items is relatively small and (d) we set the graphic to be as user friendly as possible. What is more, multilevel modelling in R handles missing values very well. Therefore, we do not plan to do any data replacement or imputation.

3. Scale reliability and structure
We are going to inspect each item using histograms and by calculating the indexes of skewness and kurtosis, as well as by inspecting Cronbach's alpha and item-rest correlation in R. We will do so to check for ceiling and floor effects, as well as normality of each item, and to investigate the reliability and the structure of each scale.

Resume evaluation: An inspection of this scale is necessary to set the multilevel model in the right way. We want to test the relationship between the four subscales of the resume evaluation, namely (a) competence, (b) cultural fit, (c) personal (dis)comfort, and (d) hireability. From a theoretical point of view, it is interesting to keep these aspects divided and run four separate multilevel models. However, if the four subscales are highly correlated merging the subscales should be considered. If this is the case, we will first run four separate models, and then compare the results to a fifth model in which the scores on the fours scales are collapsed in one score. The scores will be calculated as unweighted averages of the items.

Gender-science stereotypes: As our measure of gender-science stereotypes based on importance rating, which we devised based on previous literature, has never been used before , we will inspect the structure of this scale running an exploratory factorial analysis using the psych package in R, with predetermined two factors, representing gender-science stereotypes based on personality traits and on skills, and compare this solution to two considering -1 or +2 factors. We will eliminate those items that show a correlation with their factor that is lower than .35, and we will investigate the correlation between the factors to reach the solution the best compromises between the theory and goodness of fit with the data. Finally, we will proceed to calculate participants’ scores indexing the corresponding items, and test the correlation between the new and the old measure of gender-science stereotypes. Based on the results of these analyses, we will decide whether to include both measures of gender-science stereotypes or just the “new” one.

4. Exploratory analyses
We are going to explore the dataset by inspecting the average scores of resume’s evaluation by between-subject and within-subject conditions, to start investigating the effect of the manipulations at both levels of analyses on the main dependent variables. Second, we will explore the average scores of gender-science stereotypes by conditions of gender-essentialism, to start investigating the effect of the between-subject manipulation on the mediator. Finally, we are going to explore the correlation matrix of our main variables, which will also let us investigate the effect of the covariates on the main variables.

Before running the analyses to test our main hypothesis we are going to explore further the data using line plots for both levels of analyses. We will also perform separate regression analysis per participants and then plot the intercepts, the slopes and the Rsquared values.

sample.value: We conducted a preliminary power analysis, using the software GPower Version 3.0.10, to determine the ideal sample size. With power of .80, alpha of .05, medium effects size (f = .25), the suggested sample size was of 126. With a small effect size (f = .10) the suggested sample size was 264. We aim at collecting at least 200 responses. We are going to collect the data on a student sample from New York University.

analyses.value:
To test the effect of our manipulation of gender essentialism on people’s evaluation of LGBQs identities in STEM we are going to run a mixed multilevel model. A separate multilevel model will be run for each evaluative aspect (competence, hireability, cultural fit, and personal (dis)comfort). Person-level evaluation will be included as the dependent variable. The applicants’ sex and sexual orientation will be added as level 1 predictors, and gender essentialism condition will be included as level 2 predictor. Additionally, gender science stereotypes will be included as level 1 predictor. The multilevel models will be clustered by participants ID. Participants’ sex, sexual orientation, and political orientation will be included as covariates. We will fit the model using the function lmer in R, with estimates that optimize the log-likelihood. Before fitting the models, we will explore the data using line plots for the two levels of analysis. We will use a step-wise approach to fit the model, starting from the unconditional means model. We will compare the models using the anova function. In the unconditional means model we are going to test the intraclass correlation, which is an indicator of whether proceeding with multilevel is appropriate.

If the intraclass correlation is lower than .35 then proceeding with multilevel model is not appropriate and we will opt for repeated measure ANCOVA or repeated measure MANCOVA (if the correlation between the four sub-scales of resume’s evaluation show a correlation higher than .35) with bootstrapping.

We are going to test the mediation hypothesis with the MEDIATION package in R, which uses a quasi-Bayesian method with weak assumptions. We will test the mediation hypothesis on the final model that we will obtain from the aforementioned analyses, and the model in which gender essentialism predicts gender-science stereotypes, while controlling for the effect of  the covariates (sex, sexual orientation, and political orientation). To this last model we will add a fourth covariate indicating whether the participant passed or failed the memory task (explained later in this pre-registration). This way, if we do not find an effect of gender essentialism on gender-science stereotypes we will be able to disentangle whether our hypothesis can be rejected or whether this resulted from the non-persistence of the effect of our manipulation into the second part of the study. Depending on the results of the exploratory factor analysis on the scale of gender-science stereotypes and on the correlation between the old and the new measure of gender-essentialism, we are going to either run separate mediation analyses for each subscale of gender-science stereotypes or one multivariate mediation analysis.

outliers.value:
We are going to investigate possible outliers graphically (e.g., scatterplots of resume evaluations by condition, residuals plot), as well as through calculating Cook's Distances. We expect to find people that responded at random, as well as extreme cases. The cases that show a Cook's distance above |3 | will be excluded progressively.

We are going to exclude the responses of the participants that: (1) Did not give their consent at the end of the survey, (2) failed the attention check, (3) discovered the real intent of the study (i.e., to be about LGBQ-related issues). Next, we need to identify the participants that responded at random: We will exclude the participants that took 10 minutes or less to complete the survey, as we consider 10 minutes to be the minimum time necessary to complete the survey even at an extremely fast pace. The analysis of outliers will allow us to identify other participants that responded at random. Finally, each participant will be assigned a score based on the number of correct answers they gave to the four true/false questions regarding the article. The participants that do not have any correct answer will be excluded from further analyses.

dependent.value: Our dependent variable is LGBQ applicants’ resume evaluations compared to heterosexual applicants’ resume evaluations. The participants evaluate the resume of six students applying to a Ph.D. program in the field of Physics. They are asked to rate their agreement with eight statements, regarding four evaluative aspects: (a) competence, (b) hireability, (c) cultural fit, and (d) personal (dis)comfort at the idea of working with the applicant. Four of the six resumes are target resumes, and two are filler resumes that we added to hide the intent of the study. The evaluation task is designed as a 2 (sex: female; male) x 2 (sexual orientation: heterosexual; LGBQ) within-subject measure, as each of the four target profiles combined one of the aforementioned characteristics. Therefore, our measure of resumes’ evaluation allows us to compare the effect of gender essentialism on participants’ prejudice towards LGBQs in STEM across the three between-subject conditions, as well as to investigate individual level prejudice towards LGBQs in comparison to the evaluations of women (i.e., sexism) and heterosexual men.

conditions.value:
The participants are randomly assigned to one of three between-subject conditions: (1) support gender essentialism; (2) challenge gender essentialism; (3) control. Our manipulation of gender essentialism consists of a Neuroscientific article that presents recent findings about gender-based differences in the human brain. In the control condition, the participants read an article about Alzheimer's Disease. We added a short filler article about physics to hide the intent of the study. For the same reason, this part of the study is presented as a test about people’s understanding of scientific information. After reading each article, the participants complete four true/false questions, that we use as a manipulation check. Later on, the participants indicate their agreement with the article on a 5-point scale; we use this question as a measure of resistance to our manipulation of gender essentialism. In fact, we expect that if the participants do not believe in/disagreee with the content of the article then their beliefs in gender essentialism may not be affected by our manipulation. 

Next, each participant evaluates four different resumes (within-subject condition). Each resume is either of a man or a woman, and either of a heterosexual or LGBQ person. This part of the study is presented as a measure of people’s understanding of scientific competency.

Thus, our study has the following design: 3 (gender essentialism) between-subject X 2 (applicant’s sex) within-subject X 2 (applicant‘s sexual orientation) within-subject.

hypothesis.value: In this research project, we want to test the role of gender essentialism (e.g., gender as binary, fixed, biological) and gender-science stereotypes (e.g., science is masculine) as a barrier to the inclusion of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and queer (LGBQ) people in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) academic fields. In a first study, which we did not pre-register, we tested this question using a correlational design: the participants (N = 223) completed a series of 7-point Likert questionnaires measuring gender essentialism, modern sexual prejudice, perceived fit of LGBQs in STEM, explicit gender-science stereotypes, and modern sexism; They also responded to a reaction time task (IAT) to assess their implicit gender-science stereotypes. In Study 1, we tested our hypotheses with Structural Equation Modeling in MPlus and we found that a specific subscale of gender essentialism (i.e., gender is binary, natural, and fixed) predicted both modern sexual prejudice, and perceived fit of LGBQs in STEM, as well as gender-science stereotypes at the explicit level. Additionally, explicit gender-science stereotypes mediated the relationship between gender essentialism and perceive fit of LGBQs in STEM (but not modern sexual prejudice and modern sexism). In this second study, we are going to investigate the effect of experimentally manipulated gender essentialism (vs. gender as a dynamic construct) on the evaluation of LGBQs’ resumes applying to a Ph.D. program in STEM. We hypothesize that: (1) Supporting gender essentialism will increase the endorsement of gender-science stereotypes and negative evaluation of LGBQs, compared to the other conditions; (2) Challenging gender essentialism will decrease the endorsement of gender-science stereotypes and negative evaluation of LGBQs, compared to the other conditions; (3) Gender-science stereotypes mediate the relationship between gender essentialism and participant’s evaluations.

attributes.title: The influence of colour on performance in the context of sport: A systematic review

q1.value: The influence of colour on performance in the context of sport: A systematic review

q3.value: The present research was conceptualised to conduct a scoping review in order to systematically map and synthesise all research done investigating the influence of colour on performance in the context of sport.

q4.value: Does colour influence performance in the context of sport?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The following inclusion and exclusion criteria were established to ensure that the review parameters were clearly defined and that all literature relevant to the review objectives was identified: (a) papers must be published in the English language to ensure consistency in appraising articles; (b) papers must be original, peer-reviewed journal publications (excluding dissertation, thesis, abstract, magazine article, non-peer reviewed source); (c) papers must be available as full-text articles; (d) papers must contain empirical quantitative, qualitative or mixed-method data (excluding review, meta-analysis, commentary, letter, non-empirical article); (e) papers must involve human participants; (f) papers were excluded if they focused on instrument development and/or validation; (g) paper were excluded if they involved mentally disturbed subjects; (h) papers were excluded if they did not fit into the conceptual framework of the study dealing with the influence of colours on performance in the context of sport; (i) papers were excluded if they involved participants in activities that were not relevant to the objectives of the review.

attributes.title: The Legacy of Political Violence during the Cultural Revolution

q1.value: The Legacy of Political Violence during the Cultural Revolution: Pre-Analysis Plan

q3.value: This research investigates the effect of violence during the Cultural Revolution on contemporary public opinions in China.

q4.value:
H1a: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the insurgents during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a negative effect on trust of movement.
H1b: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the insurgents during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a positive effect on trust of government.
H2a: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the government during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a positive effect on trust of movement.
H2b: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the government during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a negative effect on trust of government.



H3a: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the insurgents during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a negative effect on contentious participation.
H3b: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the insurgents during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a positive effect on institutional participation.
H4a: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the government during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a positive effect on contentious participation.
H4b: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the government during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a negative effect on institutional participation.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: The historical dataset is compiled by Walder (2014) based on local annals of 2,213 cities and counties. The dependent variables are from the China survey conducted in 2008 by Texas A&M University and Research Center on Contemporary China at Peking University.

q13.value: The total sample size is 3989 respondents from 73 prefectures. In the specific analyses, the sample size may be smaller because of missing values.

question.value:
The independent variable of the research is regional violence intensity, which is calculated by dividing the number of total deaths by the total population, or the proportion of people killed during the Cultural Revolution. I will conduct the analysis at both the county level and aggregate county-level deaths to prefectural-level for robustness.
	The deaths have three origins, caused by government, caused by insurgents, and unknown cause. The moderator of my analysis is the proportion of deaths caused by the government. The moderator, however, can only be calculated in counties where there are no unknown origin deaths, which will lower my sample size. I will conduct the analysis removing all cases where all deaths are from unknown origin. I will also conduct an analysis which assumes that the unknown deaths are equally caused by the government and the insurgency to avoid dropping cases.
	There are four main dependent variables: trust of government, trust of movement, institutional political participation, contentious political participation. Trust of government is measured by the 4-score question “to what extent do you trust the local government”, corresponding to the independent variable which is at the locality level. Trust of movement is measured by the 5-score question “to what extent do you agree that public demonstration should be forbidden”. Institutional pollical participation is a binary variable which is 1 if the respondent has ever participated in “attend a political meeting/ contact official to express views/ contact media to express views/ contact civic organization to express views/ donate money for an organization or activity”. Contentious political participation is a binary variable which is 1 if the respondent has ever participated in “petition/ demonstration/ joining a movement group”.

The baseline specification of the model will be a linear model with an interaction term and with errors clustered at county/prefecture level depending on the unit of the independent variable. It can be written as follows where Y is the outcome, VioInt is violence intensity, ProGov is the proportion of deaths caused by the government, and the last term control variables.
Y=\beta_0+\beta_1VioInt+\beta_2ProGov+\beta_3VioInt\ast ProGov+X^T\beta
	To ensure robustness, I will also use ordinal probit/logit models, hierarchical models, and try different robust standard errors. I will also estimate an instrumental-variable model to address endogeneity issues. The instrument is the distance to sulfur mine, which determines the location of weapon factories. Counties with convenient access to military weapons are more violent during the Cultural Revolution.

H2a: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the government during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a positive effect on trust of movement.
H2b: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the government during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a negative effect on trust of government.



H3a: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the insurgents during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a negative effect on contentious participation.
H3b: For areas where violence was perpetuated by the insurgents during the Cultural Revolution, violence intensity has a positive effect on institutional participation.
